posts.name: Hieb
posts.cooked:
I’m using command based programming in java and I would like to cycle through different commands with one (or two) triggers but I’m drawing a complete blank on even what to search for.

My basic idea is to have a series of commands (Cmd1, Cmd2, Cmd3, etc) and each right trigger press will cycle through Cmd1–>Cmd2–>Cmd3 while each left trigger press will cycle back Cmd3–>Cmd2–>Cmd1.

Can anyone point me in the right direction to begin my search?

Thanks

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
That seems like a tough scheme to operate without some good feedback to the driver on which command they’re running. In my experience, even a simple fast/slow toggle can be better understood as two buttons.

I can’t think of anything that’s built-in to do exactly this, SelectCommand might be your best best. You could always build your own custom CommandGroup too.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
What youre describing is called a “state machine”.  Theres nothing specific to WPILib that would do this for you out of the box, but its fairly easy to build if you have a solid grasp of what all possible states and transitions are.

Do all of your states (i.e. the commands you want to run) involve a single subsystem?

We have some similar things we want to do, but different.

We have build a subsystem called robotState.

It had a few global variables with getter and setter methods that can be accessed via button commands in the robot container.

To be determined if this is a smart thing to do. We are trying to hand cone mode and cube mode. So the driver/operator will be able to use the same buttons for score high, score mid, ground intake… even if the elevator settings are different for the different objects.

posts.name: Hieb
posts.cooked: Thank you! For some reason I couldn’t think of the term state machine.  Yes, they are all using the same subsystem.

posts.name: Hieb
posts.cooked: That’s pretty much the same idea we had - use the triggers to cycle through either the cube or the cone scoring positions, as well as a ground pickup and “arm stowed” position.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I made an example FSM using the command-based structure as best I could to its limit for a first project. This example cycles through 4 commands with a single control. It’s a model of a 3-speed ceiling fan - pull the chain repetitively for high-med-low-off. I make no claim for beauty or efficiency but it is easy to program complicated states and changes with the structure my team uses.

For simple state changes switch/case likely would suffice.

posts.name: Christopher McDonald
posts.cooked:

posts.name: Hieb
posts.cooked: Thank you very much.  I haven’t had a chance to test it yet but I think that does what I was looking for.  .whenPressed has been deprecated but a few tweaks here and there and everything is looking like it should.

Check out:
